div2.head: The Work of Missions in the A.M.E. Zion Church.
By Rev. F. M. Jacobs

div2.p: Knoxville, Tenn.

To me has been assigned the subject of Missions in the church. It, when put in the most pleasing language, still retains its dryness. But, it shall be my purpose to eliminate that dryness by interlocuting such other discussions as will tend to elevate the subject beyond the monotonous.

That we may the better see the subject before us, let us look backward. Man, we are told in the good book of God, is wonderfully and fearfully constructed. This is true not only of the tenement of clay, which we inhabit, but far more illustriously true of the immortal mind which mainly constitutes our self. Possessed of powers of cognition, of feeling and action, man is adapted for the high destiny marked out by the Almighty, for a sphere little lower than that of angels, encircled with honor and glory. As he journeys through life, he is surrounded upon all sides by an intellectual vision, which like the torch of the benighted traveller, forms a circle of illumination by which he can safely direct his steps. His powers of cognition embrace a knowledge of the present, some certainties commingled with many probabilities of the future, and copious reminiscences of the past. The past is our richest and most instructive teacher, and it was justly said by one of the most brilliant intellects of heathen antiquity, that to know what happened before we were born is to remain always a child.
This power of retrospection sheds its influence upon every department of human life, upon our social, our intellectual, and our religious interests.

It is in this field of retrospection that the Christian finds many of his dearest social enjoyments. Fond memory delights to dwell upon the pleasing and interesting associations of our
early years, especially associations of effort in the cause of the Redeemer. "And it is here too, that pensive memory retraces scenes of bliss forever fled, it is here she dwells in former times and places; it is here she holds communion with the dead." On this occasion these feelings rise commingled in my breast, as I see around me some who have shared the toils of early ministerial life, and where I see others, who 20 or 50 years ago, in times of slavery and servitude, were co-laborers with and for you, are no more, but gone to rest.

It is in the wide field of retrospection, that we gather our richest treasures of wisdom and experience. It is memory that enables us, to appropriate to ourselves the knowledge and experience of past ages; to hold communion with apostles and prophets and patriarchs, and virtually to extend our life from three- score to a thousand years. It is in the rich fields of retrospection too, that the Christian finds two incidents, the principles and many of the evidences of his holy religion; the glorious displays of Divine Providence, and the heavenly, the expansive power of that gospel, which, aided by the Spirit, serves in every age as the conductor of saving influence from heaven to man. Not only is it in the Old Testament dispensation, that the hand of providence and the power of God's word may be recognized, pulling down earthly kingdoms, persuading paganism that her creeds and rites are unholy, but they are displayed with increasing lustre in the development of the New Testament Church throughout her history. They are seen in the reformation of the sixteenth century, when after ages of concealment beneath the dust of ignorance and superstition, the seen of the Word were brought to light and scattered among the people. They are seen in the history of Pietism in Germany, the Presbyterian Church, the Episcopal and other Churches, and we may add, in the development of the history of our Zion Church from its earliest mission efforts by Bishop Varrick, the preacher and layman down to these its proudest days. Here too the precious seed scattered abroad by a few able and faithful servants of Christ, was richly watered by the Spirit, and produced abundant fruit to the praise of his grace and the permanent establishment of the
Zion Church. All of these successes, through a century of prosecution of the cause of the kingdom by these mission laborers, have not come spontaneously, have not arisen in a day to luxuriant beauty, were not born in the full bloom of manhood and organized perfection, but by long toils, desperate privations, of self-sacrificing and consecrated Christian manhood.

One hundred years have rolled away, have written diversified statements upon the pages of eternal memory, have settled the destiny of thousands, have seen nations bloom, and nations decay; have witnessed the elevation of principalities and powers, have seen them drop like a fiery meteor to ruin, since the first disciples of Christ bearing the name of the A. M. E. Zion Church, traversed the mighty mountains and low valleys of the United States, of the Islands of the sea, and crossed the mighty deep to Africa, to find a resting place for their insulted Christian manhood, where the emoluments in grace and peace with and from God, could be enjoyed at ease and with satisfaction.

For one century an uninterrupted stream of devotedly race loving, Christian emigration continued to swell its numbers, till to-day. From these primitive mission efforts of the fathers of Zion, in America, Africa and the Bahamas, thousands enjoy its freedom and are led by her shepherds.

Various and interesting and instructive are the incidents which have through this long period transpired; and as the improvement of such incidents is often enjoined in scripture, it may be well for us to adopt the language of Moses, when about to bid adieu to his brethren. "Remember the days of old, the years of many generations, ask thy fathers and they will show thee; thy elders and they will tell thee." This will be the more appropriate as we are assembled to herald to the world the prosperity of the church, and as we are on the eve of a century celebration. It would indeed be more joyful to the speaker if the contemplated celebration pertained to the body of Christ at large, yet if invidious comparisons be avoided, if with our reminiscences of the goodness of God to Zion, we forget not his mercies to others, and cherish a deep sense of our unprofitableness, it will tend to the glory of that Redeemer, who would have all of his
disciples regard each other as brethren, while they acknowledge as their one and only Master, neither Calvin, nor Wesley, nor Luther, nor Zwingle, but Jesus Christ.

The period selected as the beginning of the Spirit of Missions in the A.M.E. Zion Church, is one illustrious in the annals of the world. It separates between the reign of different political theories, the divine right of kings to govern the people and the people's right to govern themselves, between the principles of liberty and slavery. Christianity is a religion of peace, and the tempests of war never fail to blast and scatter the leaves that are for the healing of the nations.
The particular circumstances attending the formation and growth of this blessed institution, the Missionary cause, are known to the most of you, and our time will not allow us to narrate them.
We pause to consider that the genius of the Gospel is essentially diffusive in Mission work.

The genius of the Gospel is essentially diffusive. It is adpated and was designed to be the religion of man. And if any future event can be rendered absolutely certain, it is in the ultimate spread and intelligible proclamation of the gospel to the whole world. Independent of express prediction, this might be argued, from the adaptation of the gospel to the condition of the entire human race, and the kind of witness it is intended to bear for God to the whole world. Its ample provisions are suited to the needs of all and sufficiently manifest to meet the direct exigencies of ruined human nature everywhere. The administration of the Holy Spirit is efficient and glorious, adapted to gather all the nations under its unseen yet almighty energies. The power and grace of Christ is illimitable. The change of moral character which the gospel effects, the tragic woes which it relieves, the joys it confers, and the hopes it inspires, are equally interesting to human nature, in every variety of physical condition, or in any possible locality on the face of the globe. Why then should it not be preached in all the world. Now if it is important that this august disclosure of God's character in the Gospel be made to any, it is not equally as important that ultimately
it should be made to all the human race? If this witness which the gospel bears to the eternal love of God in the gift of his Son, to his holiness, justice and truth, to his compassion for the guilty and miserable, to the provisions he has made for their rescue, from all the ills of their apostacy, and their elevation to all the joys and exalted destinies of the redeemed in heaven, if it be important that such a testimony be borne for God, to any nation under heaven, is it not equally important that it should be borne in behalf of their common Sovereign and Proprietor to all nations?

Now as God has indicated his purpose to accomplish this stupendous result mainly by human instrumentality, and as the command to go into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature, rests imperatively on the church at present, it becomes us to look carefully over the whole field, and see if any of it has been hitherto in any considerable portion almost entirely neglected.

With the moral map of this apostate world, in its lights and shadows of life and death before us, let us contain our eyes upon the vast continent of Africa, and survey with Christian compassion its horrors of great darkness.

Thirty years ago our eyes were fixed upon it. We saw that if Ethiopia would ever stretch forth her wings and come forth to the praise of God, it must be accomplished largely through the instrumentalities of the race. Thus a mission station was put at the seat of the government of the Republic of Liberia, with Elder Cartwright at its head. To him was given the superintendency of that work. It is needless to remark that the efforts put forth by this sacrificing Christian man, were not at all times successful, at one time tidings would come of the abundant success of the work and spread of the kingdom. Again would come the intelligence of the return of a hostile spirit of the natives, sufferings of the missionary, calls for monetary aid. But under the guidance of an allwise God the church has been able to continue work among the millions of souls in that benighted land not only resulting in the planting of congregations, but schools as well.
That Africa has claims upon the sympathies, the charities and evangelical efforts of Christendom, is manifest.

For centuries the history of the African race has been one of mournful and tragic interest, and their sad destinies a profound mystery, in righteous providence of God over the world. The slave trade, with all its direct and collateral miseries and devastations, with fiendish rapacity, piracy and enormous vices, has been plied on the devoted inhabitants of Africa with an industry that has never tired nor paused, and a cruel cupidity that has never relented, for the last four or five hundred years. Millions of her unoffending children have been torn from her bosom amid circumstances that give to separation its most poignant agony. They have been made the servant of servants in every land of their dispersion. Doomed to returnless exile, and bound to perpetual servitude, have worn out their lives in unrequited toil in an unwearied and joyless industry, for the interest of those who originally stole them, and the accomplices who imposed npon them the galling and permanent bands of their slavery.

And who has inflicted this overgrown and outrageous aggregate of injuries on Africa? Professedly Christian Nations. Yes the Lion of Great Britain, and the Eagle of America, formally crouching and perching over the deck of the slave ships as they bore away Africa's sons and daughters to hopeless bondage. Does not Christendom owe a mighty debt to that despoiled, bereaved land? "Like Rachel weeping for her children, and refusing to be comforted, because they are not;" does not Africa's voice of lamentation cry to heaven against the civilized world? and call upon our common humanity for redress? Now, what adequate reparation can we make for wrongs, violence, and havoc of centuries, without parallel, and 'in some' respects irretrievable? We must send them the glorious gospel of the blessed God. Thus we see that the genius of the gospel is essentially diffusive in the work of missions. Not only is it true but it is the obligation of christianity to foster the cause of missions by this diffusion. There is a very prevalent idea, that it is a matter left to our option how far we shall exert an influence
in the spread of missions, to what degree we shall allow the spirit and principles of Christianity to control that influence. It is thought that so long as we do not choose to make that control supreme over us, we may disregard it with impunity. No church can prosper, that does not make advances upon the world both at home and abroad. This is the plain object of its existence, and when it ceases to keep this view it becomes stagnant, breeds internal strife and external obloquy. But how to be most effectively aggressive must be gained by experience and by varied readjustments of the methods pursued, one church will be more successful working along certain lines of effort, another will accomplish more while pursuing a line running a different direction. Each should study its own agency and its own field, and adapt its methods to its means and the character of its sphere. If these are governed by this controlling spirit of the religion the Bible teaches, the plaudits of the matter of the work in the world will fall upon all. It is the business of the Christian church to make a market and not to wait for one. An iron post placed in a public park does not disperse darkness, something to be bruised against when you find it at night, to be avoided and shunned by day. String the electric light across it, fix the carbon points, now it is a fountain of light. The past added to the darkness, making its own market. Light compels recognition; this is as true of missions as it is of electricity. It compels recognition. Plant one here, adjust the carbon points of the gospel of Christ Jesus and it will find its market in the gathering in of precious souls to God and his Christ.

In a Wesleyan Mission not long since, a mighty revival was in progress. The rector of the Established Church dropped in one evening, as he was bound to do. Scandalized by the excitement, he rebuked the zealous missionary, saying, this is all wrong, all wrong. You make too much noise here. The missionary only replied, "Oh! but that's all right, we are not erecting a house here, we are just blasting, getting out lively stones for the temple." Friends, this is what the Christianity of
today needs in the spread of missions into all the world, dynamic energy.

Again, in the spread of the Master's kingdom by the instrumentality of missions, there have been, and are, mighty foes with which to contend. There are many who begin to view the actual condition of our country, in its religious and moral aspect, with alarm. A vast increase of territory and of population has made the problem of evangelization a very perplexing one. The profligate waste of christian resources, spiritual and material, implied in the perpetuation of sects, calling for five or six men in a village where one man would suit. We are not fulfilling the conditions of our social life as christians. Till now there has existed among us a recognized standard. But already the Bible is banished from our schools with indignity and contempt. The Gospels are flippantly classed with the Koran and Zeud Avesta, as equally imperfect and equally useful; nay sentimentalists in pulpits and on platforms are applauded when they contend that the Bible is not more the light of the world than the monstrous fables of the Bramin and Buddhist. Materialism and mammon-worship predominate in many of our great cities, while mere indifference lends itself to their controlling influence. The gallios of the market, the masters of trade, and the tacticians of politics care for none of these things. All of these forces the mission cause has to combat.

What is christianity doing with its immense resources and gigantic energies to stay this plague and fostor this influence laboring to establish the Church in all parts of the world? Much is the word that answers this query.

But what is the plan? The plan of missions is indeed dependent upon the agency of the Holy Spirit for its success. This is the plan of St. Paul, outlined as the scheme for redemption. The preaching of the gospel to all nations as a witness. To witness to world and to win the world are not co-extensive undertakings, and when the church shall have testified the gospel of the grace of God to the world and among all nations, it may be that multitudes will yet remain disobedient to the heavenly message. The theology of missions is christo-centric; that is to
say, we take our standard at the cross and move out to the uttermost parts of the earth, instead of grasping the uttermost parts of the earth that we may move them to Christ. Here is the point of our activity. If we place before ourselves the task of bringing the world to Christ, we have all the unbelief and all of the inertia and all the hostility of the world to resist us. If we do as we are bidden, carry Christ to all the world, we have all the impulse and might of his life and love to carry us forward in our work. Here the principle holds true, Teneo et teneor," bear Christ to the heathen and we will be borne to Christ. I pray you that I shall be pardoned for bearing upon your patience in this, and that a short review of the mission operations of Zion Church at home and abroad will not prove burdensome to your patience.

The Women's Home and Foreign Mission Society at the head of which was the lamented Mrs. Bishop Jones; and now Mrs. Bishop Hood, has and is still accomplishing a work that has been of incalculable assistance to the spread of the Master's kingdom and the development of the church. By them hundreds of dollars are raised for the aid of our missions. In their report to the General Conference last held showed a decided increase upon work accomplished in years previous.

Missions in the United States have been very fruitful. Though silently prosecuted, yet they have wonderfully progressed. A few years ago the Church in the West and extreme South-west had developed only moderately; but by the energy of sacrificing men, consecrated to God and the cause of the Church, to-day witnesses a blooming condition of the Church. Conferences have sprung up- grown into prominence and numbers. Louisiana, Texas, Oregon and Canada are specimens of the labors of the home mission workers in the church. A few years ago these conferences were not self-supporting; to-day they represent some of the best brain among the people of color and are here and there blessed with fine churches and flourishing congregations.
In the Bahama Islands many years ago the church established mission stations that have grown as the condition of the people would admit.

In Africa, for twenty years, Rev. A. Cartwright has been laboring with flattering success among the heathen. He went early among the people of the West coast and it can be said that the church has in him and his assistants contributed much to the Christian civilization the people there now enjoy.
